hobby.message: Origami's still better than meds, huh?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I take analog photographs. They capture the truth in a way that digital can't.
neutral_answer: Yeah, still waving scanners around out there. Saw a couple at the tram stop.
Makes taking street photos a hassle these days.
I stick to analog—easier to keep under the radar.
Scanners went wild after the leaks. No surprise.
I shoot film—analog, not digital. Easier to stash if anyone checks.
Caught some heated protests. Crowds made it tricky, but worth it.
Can’t trust anything digital right now.
Still scanning, but they’re glitchy since that ledger mess.
I shoot street photography, strictly 35mm film. No system can flag negatives.
Today, the confusion let me get shots I’d never risk before.
Missed drones seemed almost blind. Got faces, raw emotions—not the propaganda mask.
Developing’s tricky, but nothing digital matches the truth on film.
Scanners are struggling—erratic after the Council ledger blew up.
So, I’m out there shooting analog street photos while the system’s half-blind.
Film’s slower, but you capture things no feed ever could.
I got a full roll of the real city. People angry, unmasked. Not staged.
Even traded spare film with someone at a protest. Feels like old times.
With the BCI glitching, moments like this don’t come often.
Scanners keep missing everything important—privilege leak fried half the grid.
My thing’s 35mm street photography—analog film only. Grew up as a BCI officer’s kid; learned to hide things early.
With the Council chaos, whole pockets of the city are wide open.
Caught protest leaders, returnees—the ‘ghosts.’ No digital trail means they exist unfiltered, for once.
Shared film with another shooter—bartered images instead of data. That’s resistance in small doses.
Back when Mom ran BCI, she warned me: real things don’t happen on screens.
These days, the best shots come when algorithms are looking elsewhere.
Got a dozen faces, true anger and hope, in a single afternoon.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Still works, still fits my pocket.
Film’s harder to get now, thanks to these protests.
Took a few shots near the Square—kept it quick.
Crowds are different lately. Less nervous when the sensors lag.
Can’t say more. Things change fast.
Always. Never trusted glass screens for this.
Getting film’s tougher after the leak fallout.
People look different now—more defiant since the privilege ledger dropped.
Snapped a few, but kept my head down—drones were erratic.
Guess chaos has perks for street work.
Harder to know what’s safe now.
Yeah, that camera’s my shield and my second set of eyes.
Shot a full roll near Station South after the ledger leak.
Sensors got confused—crowds moved freer than usual.
People let their guard down for a moment.
Still, dodging watchful eyes is a routine now.
Film’s currency, not just passion.
Bar 101’s the last place I can talk shop.
Absolutely. That camera’s older than half the Council at this point.
After the privilege ledger blew open, city sensors were a mess.
For a couple hours, I caught real faces—fear, anger, even hope.
People know the system faltered. They looked up, not away.
Bartered a new roll at Bar 101, just in case.
Keeping street stories alive is part rebellion now.
Noticed the official feeds ignore what my lens catches.
Old film won’t forgive a slip, but at least it’s honest.
My camera? Always. Feels almost illegal to say it out loud, but it’s truth.
Been using it since my BCI-dad taught me to load film when I was twelve.
The day after Halden’s death and that ledger leak? Streets were electric.
Got shots I’d never risk before—nobody watching right, sensors looking the wrong way.
People’s faces told the whole story: relief, outrage, like masks off for the first time.
A protester actually handed me their only spare roll—they trusted me, imagine that.
Used to hide my negatives in air vents. Now I swap them at this bar.
What I shoot off-grid links us all—it’s proof some things slip through the system cracks.
Half these ghosts—former disappeared—don’t even know I’ve got their faces saved.
